org.eng.util

Class AbstractFilteringShuffleIterable<ITEM>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.eng.util.FilteringIterable<ITEM>
      • org.eng.util.AbstractFilteringShuffleIterable<ITEM>
  • Type Parameters:
    ITEM -
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterable<ITEM>, IItemReferenceIterable<ITEM>, IShuffleIterable<ITEM>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BoundedLabelValueWindowShuffleIterable, IthShuffleIterable

    public abstract class AbstractFilteringShuffleIterable<ITEM>
extends FilteringIterable<ITEM>
implements IShuffleIterable<ITEM>
    Providings filtering of items in an IShuffleIterable by extending the super class and forcing the use of IShuffleIterable in the constructor.

    This class supports implementations that would like to modify the items in a proxied IShuffleIterable to produce a modified set of items from its iterator. Implementations must provide the following methods

    • newIterable(Iterable, AbstractFilteringShuffleIterable) to create a new instance from a given set of item references, which are fundamental to IShuffleIterables.
    An important consideration when extending this class is whether or not to make the shuffles provide a repeatable set of items, albeit in a different order, or in the case where items are filtered out, to filter out a different set of items on each shuffle. The implementation allows of support of repeatability albeit at the cost of potentially having to iterate all the items to align items with their references. To enable repeatability, simply pass enforceShuffleRepeatability as true to the constructor can cause the following:
    • the values returned by getReferences() to be consistent
    • the items returned by iterator() to be the same set of items, although perhaps shuffled if shuffle(long) has been called.
    That said, other methods that might be overridden, especially when filtering on the references and not the values, include the following:
    • getFilteredReferences() to filter items on references. For example the IthShuffleIterable does this to sub-select items only based on the order of the references and not on the values of the items themselves.
    Finally, consider that depending on the filter being used, FilteringIterable.newStatefulFilter(IFilter) from the super class may need to be implemented.
    Author:
    dawood

    • Constructor Detail

      • AbstractFilteringShuffleIterable

        protected AbstractFilteringShuffleIterable(IShuffleIterable<ITEM> iterable,
                                           FilteringIterable.IFilter<ITEM> matcher,
                                           boolean enforceRepeatableShuffle)
        Create the iterable to apply the given filter to the iterable to control which items are actually produced by this instance.
        Parameters:
        iterable -
        matcher - if non-null, then filter the given iterable and if a stateful filter, then override FilteringIterable.newStatefulFilter(IFilter). If null, then sub-classes must override createFilteringIterator().
        enableShuffleRepeatability - if true, then the set of items produced by shuffling is always the same.

        public Iterable<String> getReferences()

      • getFilteredShuffleIterable

        protected IShuffleIterable<ITEM> getFilteredShuffleIterable()
        Get an iterable of only the filtered items for shuffle repeatability. If the getFilteredReferences() can not determine the references, then all items are run through this instance's filter and brought into memory in a ShufflizingIterable.
        Returns:
        never null.

      • createFilteringIterator

        protected Iterator<ITEM> createFilteringIterator()
        Create the iterator that will iterate through the references and filter them out. This is the less efficient implementation returned by iterator() that goes through each item in the underlying iterator and dis/allows as an output of this iterable. This must be overridden if passing matcher=null to the constructor. If matcher!=null, then this implementation uses the super class to create the constructor that uses the matcher to filter out items.
        Returns:

      • shuffle

        public IShuffleIterable<ITEM> shuffle()
        Description copied from interface: IShuffleIterable
        Returns a new instance of the items in this iterable that are shuffled randomly relative to the original instance. Two shuffles on the same instance should not give the same order of items. Does NOT change this instance.
        Specified by:

        Returns:

      • newIterable

        public final IShuffleIterable<ITEM> newIterable(Iterable<String> references)
        Simply call newIterable(Iterable, AbstractFilteringShuffleIterable) passing in the given argument and this instance.
        Specified by:
        newIterable in interface IShuffleIterable<ITEM>
        Parameters:
        references - the list of references to serve as a source for the iterable returned by IItemReferenceIterable.getReferences() of this instance and which ultimately produces the items from the iterable. Implementations are free to sub-select from the given list of references, but if they do then this sub-selection must be returned by the implementation's IItemReferenceIterable.getReferences() method.
        Returns:
        never null.

      • getFilteredReferences

        protected Iterable<String> getFilteredReferences()
                                          throws NoSuchElementException
        Get an iterable of the references that are responsible for producing the items from this iterable. This implementation iterates through the references of the underlying proxied iterable to try and match up the references found there with the items produced by this instance (i.e. the filtered items).

        This implementation requires the following:

        1. the filter of this instance does not add items to the set of items it produces.
        2. the proxied IShuffleIterable's iterator() produces an one item for each of the references it returns in its getReferences() method.
        For example, 
         Unfiltered iterable references : A B C D 
 Unfiltered iterator Items      : a b c d
 Filtered   iterator Items      : a   c 
 Filtered   references          : A   C
        If you find this to be the case, then either turn of the enforceShuffleRepeatability or override this implementation.
        Returns:
        never null
        Throws:
        NoSuchElementException
